Sentence: Troy falls in love with Bathsheba, enraging Boldwood
Bathsheba travels to Bath to warn Troy of Boldwood's anger, and while she (Fanny) is there, Troy convinces her (Fanny) to marry him (Troy)
With Troy supposedly dead, Boldwood becomes more and more emphatic about Bathsheba marrying him (Troy)
Boldwood holds a Christmas, to which he (Troy) invites Bathsheba and again proposes marriage; just after she (Fanny) has agreed, Troy arrives to claim her (Fanny)
Bathsheba screams, and Boldwood shoots Troy dead
